description:
From earlier lunching, of uncertain origin.
Possibly related to lunch, q.v. It is unclear which came first. Possibly influenced by nuncheon (“light snack taken in the afternoon”).

entries.meaning: A formal meal served in the middle of the day.
(obsolete) A portion of food taken at any time except at a regular meal; an informal or light repast.
examples: At twilight in the summer there is never anybody to fear—man, woman, or cat—in the chambers and at that hour the mice come out. They do not eat parchment or foolscap or red tape, but they eat the luncheon crumbs.

verbs.description: luncheon (third-person singular simple present luncheons, present participle luncheoning, simple past and past participle luncheoned)

examples: In the meantime, while ladies are luncheoning on chicken pie, or coursing in whirling britskas, performing all the singular ceremonies of a London morning in the heart of the season […]
